quote: Captain's Log, stardate 45156.1.   Our mission to Mudor Five has   been completed and since our next   assignment will not begin for   several days, we are enjoying a   welcome respite from our duties.
If it's a boy... Michael. After   my father.
Wait a minute... we decided on   Hiro, after my father.
We talked about this last night.
That's right, and we decided on   Hiro.
Wait. I've got it. How about...   William. Now there's a name...   William O'Brien. That has a nice   ring to it.
It's all right. He's just doing   somersaults.
Right... there!
He's going to be a hell of a   gymnast.
May I?
If he's not turning, he's kicking   and punching. When I want to   sleep, he wants to wake up. At   this point, I just wish it were   over.
Have to go -- I've got a   transporter simulation to run on   the bridge.
(continuing, to unborn     child)   Good-bye, Michael.
No.
Come on, Geordi
No.
Just try it once. It's not as   hard as you think. I'm telling   you... you'll be terrific.

"... I am the very model of a   modern major general, I've   information vegetable, animal and   mineral... "    (quickly embarrassed,     to Beverly)   I can't do this! I can't sing in   front of people.
Yes you can! That was terrific!       Now you were a little off pitch,   but I think we can take care of   that...
Captain, I'd like to introduce   the winners of the primary school   science fair. This is Marissa,   Jay Gordon, and Patterson.   They're here for their tour.
Hello.
How do you do?
Can we see the battle bridge?   And the torpedo bay?
I'm afraid not.    (trying to make it     sound fun)   But... we will be visiting both   the hydroponics and astrophysics   laboratories.
I'm sure you'll have a wonderful   time.
Well. If you'll come with me...
I'm not sure who to feel sorry   for... the captain or the kids.
I want you all to know that we on   the Enterprise are very proud of   the science fair winners.   Perhaps some of you will choose   to pursue a career in Starfleet.   I heartily urge you to do so.
Well, then. Ah... what did you   do for your science projects?
I planted radishes in this   special dirt and they came up all   weird!
I see. Very commendable.       And you?
An analysis of the life span of   the swarming moths of Gonal Four.       They only live for twenty hours.   Then they all die.
How interesting. And you --
Hang on -- we're falling!
What happened?
Sensors are picking up subspace   distortions and high-energy   particles directly to starboard.
Looks like we ran into a quantum   filament.       Damage report?
(reading aft science     console}   We've lost primary life-support.   Switching to secondary systems.   Impulse and warp engines are offline.
There's another filament moving   toward us, sir!
All decks brace for---
Counselor?
I'm all right.
Medical team to the bridge.
Troi to sickbay.       Troi to engineering.       Counselor Troi to any crewmember,   please acknowledge.
The computer's down, looks like   we still have impulse power...   but not much else...
Where's Lieutenant Monroe?
Counselor...
The turbolifts aren't working.       We're trapped up here.
Are you...    (tries to clear throat,     then louder)   Are you children all right?
Picard to bridge.       This is the captain. Can anyone   hear me?
Why don't they answer?
I don't know.
They're all dead.
They're not dead. Communications   are down, that's all.
We're going to die, too.
We most certainly are not --
Listen to me!
No one is going to die. The   bridge will send a rescue party   as soon as possible, so I want   you to stop crying. Everything   is going to be all right.

This is the Federation Starship   Enterprise calling any vessel   within range. We are in distress   and need assistance. Please   respond.       I'm still not sure we're even   transmitting. I'll set the   message on auto-repeat and see if   we get a response.
Are you all right?
I'm alive. What the hell   happened?
We were hit by a quantum   filament. Most of our systems   are down and we haven't been able   to contact anyone off the bridge.
Well, don't count on leaving   through there. An emergency   bulkhead closed just beneath that   lift.
Confinement mode.
Right. Isolation protocol.
I'm... not really familiar with   that protocol.
If the computer senses a hull   breach, it automatically closes   emergency bulkheads to isolate   the breach. Until we can clear   those bulkheads, we'll be cut-off   from the rest of the ship.
(reading the ops     console)   I've got partial sensors back on-line.
I'm picking up sporadic life-signs   throughout the saucer section.    There are definitely survivors.
What about Ten Forward?       My... wife is there.
I'm sorry, Chief, but the   readings aren't that specific.
Can you scan the drive section?
I'm not reading any life-signs in   the drive section.
Could the sensors be   malfunctioning?
There's no way to know. Without   the main computer, I can't run a   diagnostic.
Can you sense anything,   Counselor?
There are a lot of people still   alive... many of them are hurt...   but I can't tell where they are.
We need to start emergency   procedures. Who's the duty   officer?
Lieutenant Monroe was in command,   but he's dead.
I believe Counselor Troi is the   senior officer on the bridge.
Counselor Troi?
She carries the rank of   Lieutenant Commander.
I'd appreciate... some   suggestions.
I recommend we initiate emergency   procedure alpha two.       By-pass computer control and   place all systems on manual   override.
Very well.
Aye aye, sir.
May I suggest that our next   priority be to stabilize life-   support and try to reestablish   intership communications.
Yes.       Mister Mandel, I'd like you to   assist Ensign Ro.
Yes, sir.
How do you feel?
Okay... but a little... foggy.
Just lie still for a while.   We'll get you to sickbay as soon   as we can.
Report.
I have made a survey of all   turbolifts and service crawlways   on this deck. Our access to the   bridge has been completely   severed by emergency bulkheads.
Sickbay?
Heavy damage in section twenty-   three-A has cut-off access to   sickbay. I have ordered a   security team to move all   casualties on this deck to Ten   Forward until further notice.
We should assume the worst...   that everyone on the bridge is   dead and no one is in control of   the ship.
In that circumstance,    reestablishing control should   be our top priority.
Agreed. Can we get to   engineering?
The direct route is blocked, but   there might be a way to reach it   through a starboard service   crawlway.
Okay -- you and I will try to get   there. Worf, this room is going   to be filled with wounded in a   few minutes and they're going to   need help. I want you to remain   in charge here.
Yes, sir.
Let's go.
Bring her here!
Okay... clear the power shunt...   bypass the flow current...   and...
(frustrated, to     Beverly)   The computer still won't release   the doors.
Can we force them open?
We can try. There's an emergency   hand actuator.
Geordi...
Yes?
Geordi, this wall's hot.
I'm all right.    (beat, then he looks     back at the wall     panel)   But I think we've got a new   problem.
One of the energy conduits   must've ruptured and ignited the   polyduranide inside the bulkhead.   That's a plasma fire.
It's putting out a lot of   radiation. We can't stay in here   very long.

We've got a bigger problem than   that.       The quaratum in these containers   is used in emergency thruster   packs. It's normally pretty   stable stuff... but when you   expose quaratum to radiation it   has a way of... exploding.
The external power has been cut   off.
We're going to die.
What was that?
I don't know.
Your name... is Marissa. Is that   right?
How old are you?
Nine. And a half.
Really? And the boys?
Seven... and six.
Well, I'm going to need a first   officer to help me. You're the   oldest... so that makes you   Number One.
Number One?
That's what I've always called my   first officer. Here.
Now... we need a crew to help us   get that hatch off.
Number One... I think Jay might   make an excellent science   officer. Don't you agree?
Yes. Yes, sir, Captain.
Will you join our crew, Jay?
Excuse me. It's Jay Gordon.
Of course. Forgive me. Jay   Gordon.
I accept.
Can I be an officer, too?
Let's see... your science project   involved radishes, did it not?
Yeah... weird ones.
Excellent. You'll be our   executive officer in charge of   radishes.
Now -- let's get to work.
Thirteen-sixty-five-baker. That   should put us near shuttlebay   two.
That is correct, sir. We have   approximately fifty-two meters   remaining in this crawlway before   we can safely exit into a main   corridor.
Coolant leak!
We can withstand this level of   radiation for another three or   four hours without any permanent   damage.       But we'll need a few days of   hyronalin treatments.
What are the radiation levels in   the quaratum?
They're at eighty-three rads and   rising about four rads per   minute.
That stuff gets unstable at   around three hundred fifty rads.       I still can't get any power to   this transporter.
The radiation levels are twenty   percent lower at this end of the   bay. Let's move the containers   over here.
That should buy us some time.       We're going to have to do this by   hand. With this much radiation   flying around in here we can't   trust the anti-grav units.
There. Just before the second   time we were hit... see the   subspace distortion?
Yes.       How big are these quantum   filaments?
They can be hundreds of meters   long, but they have almost no   mass... which is why they're so   difficult to detect.
So, it's like a... cosmic string?
No... that's a completely   different phenomenon.
How'd you do that?
I diverted power from the phaser   array and dumped it into the   engineering control system.
You what?
The engineering station's on-line,   Counselor.
That's a completely improper   procedure. You can't dump that   much raw energy into a bridge   terminal without---
We aren't going to get out of   this by playing it safe.
What's our engine status, Ensign?
We've got half impulse power   available.       But I'm getting some odd readings   from the warp drive...
I'm reading a spike in the warp   field array... looks like a   containment deviation...
Switch to primary bypass...
Nothing. Field strength's at   forty percent and falling.
We've got a problem. The quantum   resonance of the filament caused   a polarity shift in the antimatter   containment field.
When the filament hit us, the   ship was momentarily charged...   as if it had... come into   contact with a live electrical   wire.
That weakened the containment   field surrounding the antimatter   pods. The field strength is down   to forty percent and it's still   falling.
If it falls to fifteen percent...   the field will collapse and   there'll be a containment breach.
Which means... ?
The ship will explode.
The current cannot be shut down   from this relay box.
We can't just sit here.
If the energy flowing through   this arc were interrupted by a   nonconductive material, it is   likely that the circuit would be   broken.
I don't see any material in here   that could stop that much   current.
Commander, most of my bodyframe   is composed of tripolymers, a non-   conductive material.
You're suggesting using your own   body?
Yes, sir.
Data, there's at least half a   million amps flowing through that   arc. Can you take that much   current?
The power surge would cause a   system failure in most of my   internal processors and melt my   primary power couplings.   However, there is a chance that   the damage would not be   irreparable.
No.
Commander, our choices are very   limited.
First of all, android or not, I   won't allow anyone to take that   kind of risk. Second, if the   computer isn't working in   engineering, I'm going to need   your help to get control of the   ship.
My positronic brain has several   layers of shielding to protect it   from power surges. It would be   possible for you to remove my   cranial unit and take it with   you.
You want me to take your head   off?
(surprised at the     reaction)   Yes, sir.       Is there something wrong?
Well, Data... it's just... I   mean, will you be all right?
My neural nets and memory core   are self-contained.       I will be fine.
Like you said... our choices are   very limited.
Data? Data!
A remarkable experience,   Commander.
How are you? Did the shielding   work?
Apparently so. My neural nets   are fully operational.       You may begin by opening the   ventral access panel located two   centimeters beneath my right ear.
Feel around the edge of the   illumination module -- of the big   circle, until you find a small   knob.
I have it.
Now with your other hand, reach   around the far side of the   module... there should be another   knob.
Okay, I found it.
Good. Good. Pull both knobs out   at the same time and then let go.
Now push up... and slide the   hatch over to the side.
Jay Gordon, can you pull yourself   up?
Yes. I think so.
Can you tell what deck we're on?   There should be a large number on   the wall of the shaft.
It says "eleven".
Good. Now look down at the side   of the lift. Do you see two big   clamps?
Yes.
Can you see if both clamps are   connected to a... long beam   inside a... a big groove?
Yes. But one of them looks   broken. It's half out of the   groove.
All right. Come down.
Number One, those big clamps are   part of the emergency system. If   something goes wrong, they're   designed to hold the turbolift in   place.
But they seem to have been   damaged.
Is that why we keep shaking?

That's right.       When that clamp gives way, we'll   fall. You're going to have to   take your crew out of here before   that happens. There's a ladder   along the inside of the   turboshaft. You can use it to   climb up until you find an open   doorway.
What about you?
My leg is broken. I'll only slow   you down and you need to move   quickly.       You'll have to be the leader.   That's an order.
We have to climb up the shaft.
What about the captain?
I'm not going. Commander Marissa   is in charge.
I wanna stay here with you.
Patterson, you're an officer,   now. You have to obey orders.
I don't wanna be an officer   anymore. I wanna stay with you.
If the captain stays here, we   won't make it. We'll all die.
There's no time to argue, you   have to go now.
I don't want to!
The crew has decided to stick   together. We all go or we all   stay.
All right. I'll try. But I want   you to know... this is mutiny.
Number One, look at that panel...   do you see a bright yellow cap?
Yes.
Pull the cap toward you and then   turn it... it should come off.
Good. Now, that bundle of   wires... that's optical   cabling... see how much you can   pull out...
The levels are still rising.
There must be some way to put   that thing out.
The energy's being fed by the   ship's internal power grid and we   can't even get near that. The   only way to stop it would be to   eliminate the supply of oxygen.       Wait a minute...
Doctor, I've got an idea. It's   pretty wild, but we might be able   to kill two birds with one stone.
Let's hear it.
If we open the external door it   would depressurize the cargo bay,   and blow all those containers out   into space. At the same time,   the lack of oxygen should knock   out the plasma fire.
What about us?
We'll have to find something in   here to hang onto while the air   is evacuated. After that, we'll   shut the door and repressurize   the bay.
This looks like it'll have to do.
There... that should do it.
There will be a sharp pain as I   set the bone. Prepare yourself.
Good... good. You bore that   well.
I'm all right... I think...
Perhaps you should lie down.
Okay.
I'm having contractions...
I believe that is not uncommon in   the late months of pregnancy...
I mean contractions... I'm going   into labor.
You cannot. This... this is not   a good time.
It's not open for debate. Like   it or not -- this baby is coming.
If the containment field strength   keeps dropping at this rate, we   still have at least two hours   before it becomes critical.

But you're ignoring the fact that   the power coupling is also   damaged.       If that coupling overheats, the   field strength will begin to drop   a lot faster. We could have a   containment breach in a matter of   minutes.
What do you suggest?
We should separate the saucer   now, and put as much distance as   possible between us and the drive   section.
Excuse me, sir, but that's damn   cold-blooded. What about the   people down there?
There's no evidence anyone is   still alive in the drive section.
There's no evidence they're dead,   either. If you were trapped down   there, would you want us to cut   you loose and leave?
Of course not. But I also   wouldn't expect the bridge crew   to risk the safety of the ship   and hundreds of lives in a futile   effort to rescue me.
(without turning     around)   You said there's no way to   stabilize the containment field   from the bridge. Could it be   done from engineering?
Yes... but my readings indicate   there's no power down there.   They don't even have monitors to   tell them there's a problem.
Could we divert energy from the   bridge... to those monitors?
Yes, sir.
I'll say it again: there's no   reason to believe anyone's alive   in engineering. We're wasting   time even talking about this. We   have to separate the ship now.
I believe there are people still   alive down there... and I'm   going to give them every chance.
Assuming they are alive, they'll   be hoping there's someone up here   to help them. So we'll help   them.    (to O'Brien   Divert the necessary power to   engineering.
Aye, sir.
I remind you, Counselor... that   power coupling could overheat at   any time. By not separating the   ship now, you may be responsible   for all our deaths.
Thank you, Ensign. Proceed.
I can't open this door.
We'll have to climb up to the   next deck.
What if that one doesn't open   either?
Then we'll never get out.
Quiet. That's an order.
We're going up. Ready?
Ready, sir.
The lift's falling! Hang on!
We're all right. We're going to   keep climbing. Don't look down.
What's wrong?
He's scared.
We're right here with you,   Patterson. You're not going to   fall.
Everything will be all right if   you keep moving.
What we need -- is a climbing   song. Marissa, what's a song you   sing in school?
"The Laughing Vulcan and His Dog"?
I'm afraid I don't know that one.       I know -- "Frere Jacques". We   used to sing that when I was your   age. Patterson, do you know that   song?
It goes like this... "Frere   Jacques, Frere Jacques... "
"... dormez vous, dormez vous... "
"... sonnez les matines, sonnez   les matines, ding din dong, ding   din dong. Frere Jacques... "
"... Frere Jacques, dormez vous,   dormez vous... "
Your contractions are now only   twenty seconds apart.
It feels like they're constant...
They will continue to come closer   together until you reach the   bearing down phase.
Dilation has gone to nine   centimeters since the onset of   labor.       That did not take long.
Easy for you to say...
You are doing very well. I am   sure the child will arrive soon.
Worf... has the baby turned?
Turned... ?
So the head is down. Doctor   Crusher told me a few days ago it   hadn't... but she wasn't worried   because I still had a month to   go...
I am not certain.       Can't you tell?
Worf... have you ever done this   before? Delivered a baby?
No. But I have taken the   Starfleet Emergency Medical   Course. In a computerized   simulation, I assisted in the   delivery of a human baby.
Sometimes... things don't go by   the book...
I am sure everything will be   fine.

Once the air is vented, the first   thing you'll feel is extreme   pressure in your lungs... you'll   have to resist the temptation to   exhale. Next, your hands and   feet will get cold, then numb...   and some of the capillaries in   exposed sections of skin may   burst.
Sounds like fun.
We'll have about fifteen seconds   of useful consciousness left.   After that, there's about ten   seconds of extreme   disorientation, then we pass out.
(indicates panel on far     wall)   After the air has been evacuated,   one of us will have to get to   that panel and repressurize the   bay.
We're ready.
The field strength is down to   twenty percent. We can't run the   risk of staying here any longer.
We're not in danger until it   drops below fifteen percent. We   can afford to wait and see if   anyone in engineering notices   those monitors.
Have you made preparations to   separate the Saucer Section?
Yes, sir. We're in stand-by mode   for docking latches and --
Ensign -- there's a thermal   inversion in the power coupling!
Quick... cross-connect it to the   transfer coil.
What happened?
Exactly what I said might happen.   The power coupling overheated and   the entire containment field   almost collapsed.

O'Brien's fixed it temporarily,   but it could happen again at any   moment, and next time we might   not be able to stop it. You   can't let wishful thinking guide   your decision. It's time to   leave, Counselor.
We will separate the ship when I   have decided that it's time, not   before. Is that clear, Ensign?
Yes. Perfectly.
Okay, try it.
Very good, Commander. You have   established the connection. I   can now raise the door.
There's no power on the entire   deck, but somehow these monitors   are working.
Commander, the power reaching   those monitors has been diverted   from the bridge.
But why... ?       Unless there's something they   want us -- something they need us   to see...
Data -- the containment field   strength is down to eighteen   percent!
Can you stabilize it?
I do not have access to the   containment field. You will have   to establish a new link.
Locate the ODN conduit.
Got it.
You must now change the input   matrix in my secondary optical   port and then connect the ODN   conduit.
That is not the correct port,   sir.
Sorry.
Commander, you must hurry, the   field has dropped to sixteen   percent.
I'm trying. You need a bigger   head.
The field is still dropping --   collapse is imminent.
All right, try it!
I have a connection.       I am now stabilizing the   containment field.
That's using your head, Data.
All right. Stand by to separate   the Saucer Section --
Sir... the field strength is   stabilizing...
Eighteen percent... twenty...   twenty-five...
I guess they got our message.
I was wrong, Counselor.
You could have just as easily   been right.
Congratulations. You are fully   dilated to ten centimeters.       You may now give birth.
I thought that's what I've been   trying to do...
Bearing down is the next stage.   It should start at full dilation.   Why has it not begun?
I don't know... I don't think   it's up to me... it happens when   it happens...
My computer simulation was not   like this. That delivery was   very orderly.
Well, I'm sorry...
Did you feel an uncontrollable   urge to push?
Good! You are bearing down. Now   you must push with each   contraction and I must urge you   gently but firmly to push harder.
Push, Keiko. Push hard...
Push... push...
(through clenched     teeth)   I am pushing --
The baby is emerging head first.   One more contraction...
Okay...
That's good -- push... harder...       I have the baby!
I will now smack the child to   induce breathing --
I believe she looks like Chief   O'Brien.
You were wonderful, Worf. I   couldn't have done it without   you.
Captain's log, supplemental. We   are en route to Starbase Sixty-seven,   to undergo repairs. Life   aboard the Enterprise is slowly   returning to normal.
Just can't stay away from the big   chair anymore, can you?
I don't think I'm cut out to be   captain... first officer,   maybe... I understand there   aren't many qualifications.
Captain Picard to the bridge,   please.
There are some visitors here to   see you, Captain.
Hello. It's good to see you   again. What brings you to the   bridge?

"In appreciation for the way you   helped us get out of the   turboshaft, and the way you   helped us not be scared."       We want to present to you this   com-mem-mor-a-tive plaque.    (whispers to Jay     Gordon)   Give it to him.
Thank you, very much.
I made the back piece.
And you did a wonderful job.   Later this afternoon, we'll   finish the tour I promised you.       Starting with the battle bridge.
I'll see you at fourteen hundred   hours.    (as he turns to go to     the Ready Room)   You have the bridge, Number One.
Aye, sir.
